question.title: Reverse Subarray To Maximize Array Value
question.content:
You are given an array of integers ‘NUMS’. The beauty of this array can be defined as:

The sum of absolute difference of each two consecutive elements.

In one operation you can reverse one subarray of ‘NUMS’. Your task is to find maximum beauty by performing the operation exactly once.

Input Format:
The first line contains an integer ‘T’, which denotes the number of test cases to be run. Then, the ‘T’ test cases follow.

The first line of each test case contains a single positive integer ‘N’ denoting the size of the ‘NUMS’ array. 

The second line of each test case contains ‘N’ space-separated positive integers denoting the array elements.
Output Format:
For each test case, print a single line containing a single integer denoting the maximum beauty of the array ‘NUMS’ by doing the operation described above exactly once.

The output of each test case will be printed in a separate line.
Note:
You do not need to print anything. It has already been taken care of. Just implement the given function.
Constraints:
1 <= ‘T’ <= 10
1 <= ‘N’ <= 10^5
1 <= NUMS[i] <= 10^8

Where ‘N’ is the size of the array ‘NUMS’ and ‘NUMS[i]’ is the ith element of the array.

Time Limit: 1 sec
Sample Input 1:
1
5
5 4 1 7 2
Sample Output 1:
17
Explanation for sample input 1:
The current beauty of the array is |5 - 4| + |4 - 1| + |1 - 7| + |7 - 2| = 15, after reversing the subarray [4, 1, 7, 2] beauty becomes = |5 - 2| + |2 - 7| + |7 - 1| + |1 - 4| = 17, which is the maximum beauty we can obtain.
Sample Input 2:
2
4
4 3 7 1
5
4 5 3 7 6
Sample Output 2:
13
10
Explanation for sample input 2:
For test case 1, the initial beauty value is 1 + 4 + 6 = 11, on reversing the subarray [3, 7, 1] the beauty becomes 3 + 6 + 4 = 13.

For test case 2, reverse the subarray [5, 3, 7] to get a beauty value of 10.

rephrased.body: Given an array of integers 'NUMS', its beauty is defined as the sum of the absolute differences between each pair of consecutive elements. You are allowed to reverse one subarray of 'NUMS' exactly once. The goal is to find the maximum possible beauty of the array after performing this single reversal operation.
constraints: Where ‘N’ is the size of the array ‘NUMS’ and ‘NUMS[i]’ is the ith element of the array.

testcases.explanation: The initial beauty of the array [5, 4, 1, 7, 2] is |5-4| + |4-1| + |1-7| + |7-2| = 1 + 3 + 6 + 5 = 15. By reversing the subarray [4, 1, 7, 2], the array becomes [5, 2, 7, 1, 4]. The beauty of the reversed array is |5-2| + |2-7| + |7-1| + |1-4| = 3 + 5 + 6 + 3 = 17. This reversal yields the maximum achievable beauty.

The initial beauty value is |4-3| + |3-7| + |7-1| = 1 + 4 + 6 = 11. Reversing the subarray [3, 7, 1] transforms the array into [4, 1, 7, 3]. The beauty of the array is now |4-1| + |1-7| + |7-3| = 3 + 6 + 4 = 13.
Reversing the subarray [5, 3, 7] gives the maximum beauty of 10.

hints: Think of a brute force approach. Check the answer for every subarray.
Do we really need to calculate the beauty of the whole array for each possible subarray?
Does the beauty of the array increase with every swap of left and right? Or are there only certain cases that improve our answer?
